name: Pentagram
description: The Pentagram is one of the most powerful and widely recognized symbols in Western esoteric tradition. This five-pointed star, drawn with a single continuous line, represents the microcosm of humanity and the macrocosm of the universe. Its proportions embody the golden ratio, making it a supreme symbol of sacred geometry and divine harmony. Throughout history, it has served as a protective talisman, a symbol of the five elements, and a key to understanding the relationship between humanity and the cosmos.
meaning: The five-pointed star representing the five elements (Earth, Water, Fire, Air, Spirit), the microcosm of humanity, sacred geometry through the golden ratio, and the balance of elemental forces in Western esoteric tradition.
visualDescription: A five-pointed star formed by drawing five straight lines that create a continuous, interlocking pattern. The figure can be inscribed within a circle (pentacle) and features the golden ratio in the proportions between its lines. When drawn with one point upward, it represents spirit presiding over matter; inverted, it symbolizes matter dominating spirit.
meanings: The five classical elements: Earth, Water, Fire, Air, and Spirit (Quintessence)
The microcosm - humanity as a reflection of the divine cosmos
Sacred geometry and the golden ratio (phi = 1.618...)
Protection and banishment of negative forces
The five senses and five extremities of the human body
Unity of the four material elements under spiritual governance
The Pythagorean symbol of health and recognition
Balance and harmony between opposing forces

upright.name: Upright Pentagram
upright.description: Single point facing upward, representing Spirit governing the four material elements
symbolism: The macrocosm reflected in the microcosm

inverted.name: Inverted Pentagram
inverted.description: Two points facing upward, representing matter dominating spirit
symbolism: Second degree initiation in some traditions
inverted.historicalContext: The inverted pentagram was not originally considered evil. In ceremonial magic, it represents the second degree of initiation where the aspirant must confront material existence. Its association with Satanism dates primarily to the 19th century through the writings of Eliphas Levi.

goldenRatio.description: The pentagram is the supreme expression of the golden ratio (phi, approximately 1.618034). Every line segment in a pentagram relates to others by the golden ratio.
mathematicalProperties: The ratio of the diagonal to the side equals phi
Each intersection creates segments in golden proportion
The pentagram contains infinite nested pentagrams, each related by phi
goldenRatio.significance: The golden ratio appears throughout nature in growth patterns, spiral shells, flower petals, and the proportions of the human body. The pentagram thus represents the mathematical signature of organic life and divine creation.

methods: Compass and straightedge using golden ratio relationships
Five equal divisions of a circle (72 degrees apart)
Connecting every second point of a regular pentagon
construction.symbolism: The ability to construct a perfect pentagram with compass and straightedge represents the union of geometric precision with organic harmony.

sacredGeometry.pentagonRelationship: The pentagram and pentagon are intimately related - a pentagram inscribed in a pentagon creates a smaller pentagon at its center, which can contain another pentagram, ad infinitum. This infinite regression symbolizes the fractal nature of reality.

prehistoric.details: The earliest known pentagrams appear in Sumerian pottery and astronomical texts, where they represented the planet Venus and its five-pointed path across the sky over an eight-year cycle.

pythagorean.details: The Pythagoreans adopted the pentagram as their secret symbol of recognition, calling it 'Hugieia' (Health). They discovered its mathematical properties and considered it a symbol of perfection and the golden ratio.
significance: Demonstrated the golden ratio's presence in geometry

usage: Symbol of the five wounds of Christ
Representation of the Star of Bethlehem
Carved on church doorways and grave markers
christian.examples: Sir Gawain and the Green Knight describes the pentangle on Gawain's shield as representing the five virtues of knighthood, the five joys of Mary, and the five wounds of Christ.

developments: Association with the human microcosm (Vitruvian proportions)

goldenDawn.organization: Hermetic Order of the Golden Dawn

lesserBanishingRitual.name: Lesser Banishing Ritual of the Pentagram (LBRP)
lesserBanishingRitual.description: The foundational ritual of Golden Dawn magic, used to clear a space of unwanted influences and establish a protected magical working area.
components: Drawing pentagrams at the four quarters

greaterRitual.name: Greater Ritual of the Pentagram
greaterRitual.description: Advanced form using specific pentagrams for invoking or banishing each element, utilizing the elemental attributions of the pentagram's points.
variations: Invoking pentagrams (draw toward the element's point)
Banishing pentagrams (draw away from the element's point)
Spirit Active and Spirit Passive pentagrams

elemental.invokingMethod: To invoke an element, draw the pentagram starting from the point opposite that element and moving toward it.
elemental.banishingMethod: To banish an element, draw the pentagram starting from that element's point and moving away from it.
elemental.spiritActive: Used with Fire and Air (masculine elements)
elemental.spiritPassive: Used with Water and Earth (feminine elements)

starRuby.name: The Star Ruby
starRuby.description: Crowley's Thelemic reformulation of the LBRP, using Greek and Egyptian god-names instead of Hebrew divine names.
elements: NOX signs replacing the Qabalistic Cross
Greek deity invocations (Therion, Nuit, Babalon, Hadit)

liber36.name: The Star Sapphire
liber36.description: A sexual magical ritual incorporating pentagram symbolism with the union of opposites.

thelema.philosophy: In Thelema, the pentagram represents the microcosm and the individual will. The formula of the pentagram is the formula of the initiated human being in harmony with the universe.

solomonic.keyOfSolomon: The Key of Solomon features the pentagram prominently in its protective seals and magical operations.

wiccan.significance: The pentagram is the primary symbol of Wicca, representing the five elements and the interconnection of all life.

pentacle.description: A pentagram enclosed within a circle, often worn as jewelry or placed on the altar
usage: Primary altar tool representing Earth element

initiation.firstDegree: Upright pentagram - the beginning of the path
initiation.secondDegree: Inverted pentagram - facing the material world
initiation.thirdDegree: Return to upright - mastery and teaching

wiccan.sabbats: The pentagram appears in rituals throughout the Wheel of the Year, often drawn in the air or used as a consecrating symbol.

usage: Representation of the Goddess and God
Connection to nature and natural cycles

symbolism: The five wounds of Christ (hands, feet, side)

gnostic.tradition: Christian Gnostic and early Christian mysticism

christianUsage.decline: The pentagram's association with Christianity declined during the witch trial era (15th-18th centuries) as it became associated with folk magic and eventually with occultism through the writings of Eliphas Levi.

freemasonry.name: Blazing Star
freemasonry.symbolism: Divine Providence, the search for light and truth, the five points of fellowship

bahai.name: Haykal (Temple)
bahai.symbolism: The human body, the temple of God, representing the head, two hands, and two feet

mormonism.usage: Appears on early Mormon temples, including the Nauvoo Temple, representing the morning star

judaism.name: Seal of Solomon (alternate form)
judaism.usage: Occasionally used alongside the hexagram in Kabbalistic contexts

ritualUsage: The pentagram is used extensively in ceremonial magic, Wiccan practice, and various esoteric traditions for: protection and banishing, invoking elemental forces, creating sacred space, meditation and visualization, consecration of tools and spaces, and as a symbol of initiation and spiritual attainment.

variations.name: Pentacle
variations.description: Pentagram enclosed in a circle, emphasizing containment and unity

variations.name: Flaming Pentagram
variations.description: Pentagram with flames at each point, representing spiritual fire

variations.name: Elemental Pentagram
variations.description: Pentagram with elemental symbols at each point

variations.name: Unicursal Hexagram
variations.description: Related six-pointed figure that can be drawn in one line, used in Thelema

variations.name: Invoking/Banishing Pentagrams
variations.description: Different starting points and directions for different magical purposes

usage: meditation, ritual magic, protection, elemental invocation, consecration, talismanic work, spiritual development
